message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Nonreciprocal Ising Model
Paper Abstract: Systems with nonreciprocal interactions generically display time-dependent states. These are routinely observed in finite systems, from neuroscience to active matter, in which globally ordered oscillations exist. However, the stability of these uniform nonreciprocal phases in noisy spatially-extended systems, their fate in the thermodynamic limit, and the critical behavior of the corresponding phase transitions are not fully understood. Here, we address these questions by introducing a nonreciprocal generalization of the Ising model and study its phase transitions by means of numerical and analytical approaches. While the mean-field equations predict three stable homogeneous phases (disordered, ordered, and a time-dependent swap phase), our large scale numerical simulations reveal a more complex picture. Static order is destroyed in any finite dimension due to the growth of rare droplets unless the symmetry between the two spin types is broken, triggering a stabilizing droplet-capture mechanism. The swap phase is destroyed by fluctuations in two dimensions through the proliferation of spiral defects but stabilized in three dimensions, where nonreciprocity changes the critical exponents from Ising to XY, thus giving rise to a robust spatially-distributed clock.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
**Step 2: Identifying all triples from the title and abstract**

Let me extract the key entities and their relationships:

**USES (existing concepts/methods):**
1. **Ising Model** - The foundation model being generalized (concept/method)
2. **Phase transitions** - The theoretical framework (concept)
3. **Mean-field theory/equations** - Analytical approach used (method)
4. **Numerical simulations** - Computational approach used (method)
5. **Critical exponents** - Theoretical concept used to characterize transitions (concept)
6. **Nonreciprocal interactions** - Core concept framework (concept)
7. **Spin systems** - Task/framework (concept)

**PROPOSES (new contributions):**
1. **Nonreciprocal Ising Model** - The novel model itself (method/artifact)

Links: [{"title":"Critical exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_exponent"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Critical exponent of a word - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_exponent_of_a_word"},{"title":"Percolation critical exponents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percolation_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Critical phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_phenomena"},{"title":"Category:Critical exponents (phase transitions) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Critical_exponents_(phase_transitions)"},{"title":"Critical dimension - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_dimension"},{"title":"Directed percolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_percolation"},{"title":"Rushbrooke inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rushbrooke_inequality"},{"title":"Widom scaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widom_scaling"}]

Here's information about critical exponents based on the search results:

## Definition

Critical exponents describe the behavior of physical quantities near continuous phase transitions.

## Key Characteristics

It is believed, though not proven, that they are universal, i.e. they do not depend on the details of the physical system, but only on some of its general features.(no content)These exponents are robust observables that take the same values for very different physical systems.(no content)This intriguing phenomenon, called universality, is explained, qualitatively and also quantitatively, by the renormalization group.

## Physical Significance

Critical phenomena include scaling relations among different quantities, power-law divergences of some quantities (such as the magnetic susceptibility in the ferromagnetic phase transition) described by critical exponents, universality, fractal behaviour, and ergodicity breaking.

## Computation and Study

Critical exponents can be evaluated via Monte Carlo methods of lattice models, the renormalization group is the most widely applicable technique, and the conformal bootstrap has achieved unsurpassed accuracy for the Ising critical exponents.

Critical exponents are fundamental quantities in statistical physics that help classify phase transitions into universality classes based on their shared critical behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_defect"},{"title":"Talk:Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Topological_defect"},{"title":"Texture (cosmology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texture_(cosmology)"},{"title":"Sinéad Griffin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sin%C3%A9ad_Griffin"},{"title":"Crystallographic defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystallographic_defects"},{"title":"Tom Kibble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_W._B._Kibble"},{"title":"Homotopy colimit and limit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homotopy_colimit_and_limit"},{"title":"Domenica Garzón - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domenica_Garz%C3%B3n"}]

Here's an overview of topological defects based on the search results:

## Definition and Characteristics

Topological defects are structures in a physical system that are stable against perturbations. Topological defects are not only stable against small perturbations, but cannot decay or be undone or be de-tangled, precisely because there is no continuous transformation that will map them to a uniform or "trivial" solution.

## How They Form

The existence of a topological defect can be demonstrated whenever the boundary conditions entail the existence of homotopically distinct solutions, typically occurring because the boundary has a non-trivial homotopy group which is preserved in differential equations.

## Examples

Topological defects include monopoles, cosmic strings, or domain walls. Vortices in superfluids and pinned vortex tubes in type-II superconductors provide examples of topological solitons in fluids. Additionally, in crystallography, topological defects are regions in a crystal where the normal chemical bonding environment is topologically different from the surroundings.

## Applications

Topological defects occur in partial differential equations and are believed to drive phase transitions in condensed matter physics. The paradigmatic mechanism of defect formation across a second-order phase transition is known as the Kibble-Zurek mechanism.

Cristina Marchetti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M._Cristina_Marchetti"},{"title":"Vicsek model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicsek_model"},{"title":"John Toner (physicist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Toner_(physicist)"},{"title":"Hans Elsässer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Els%C3%A4sser"},{"title":"Category:Soft matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Soft_matter"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Peer review/Bash.org/archive1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Peer_review/Bash.org/archive1"},{"title":"Template talk:Episode list - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Episode_list"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of **active matter** based on the search results:

## Definition and Characteristics

Active matter is matter composed of large numbers of active "agents", each of which consumes energy in order to move or to exert mechanical forces.(no content)Such systems are intrinsically out of thermal equilibrium.(no content)Active matter systems break time reversal symmetry because energy is being continually dissipated by the individual constituents.

## Examples

Most examples of active matter are biological in origin and span all the scales of the living, from bacteria and self-organising bio-polymers such as microtubules and actin (both of which are part of the cytoskeleton of living cells), to schools of fish and flocks of birds.(no content)However, a great deal of current experimental work is devoted to synthetic systems such as artificial self-propelled particles.

## Research Methods

Research in active matter combines analytical techniques, numerical simulations and experiments, with notable analytical approaches including hydrodynamics, kinetic theory, and non-equilibrium statistical physics.

## Key Models

Active matter is a relatively new material classification in soft matter: the most extensively studied model, the Vicsek model, dates from 1995.(no content)The Vicsek model consists in point-like self-propelled particles that evolve at constant speed and align their velocity with their neighbours' one in presence of noise.

Web search results for query: "Ising Model"

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Square lattice Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model"},{"title":"Transverse-field Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse-field_Ising_model"},{"title":"High-dimensional Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-dimensional_Ising_model"},{"title":"Two-dimensional critical Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-dimensional_critical_Ising_model"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Ernst Ising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising"},{"title":"Construction of an irreducible Markov chain in the Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_of_an_irreducible_Markov_chain_in_the_Ising_model"},{"title":"Spherical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_model"},{"title":"Swendsen–Wang algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swendsen%E2%80%93Wang_algorithm"}]

## Ising Model

The Ising model, named after the physicists Ernst Ising and Wilhelm Lenz, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics.(no content)The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1).

### Structure and Interactions

The spins are arranged in a graph, usually a lattice (where the local structure repeats periodically in all directions), allowing each spin to interact with its neighbors.(no content)Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.

### Historical Development

The Ising model was invented by the physicist Wilhelm Lenz (1920), who gave it as a problem to his student Ernst Ising.(no content)The one-dimensional Ising model was solved by Ising (1925) alone in his 1924 thesis; it has no phase transition.(no content)The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is much harder and was only given an analytic description much later, by Lars Onsager (1944).

### Significance

The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is one of the simplest statistical models to show a phase transition.(no content)Today, each year, about 800 papers are published that use the model to address problems in such diverse fields as neural networks, protein folding, biological membranes and social behavior.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Mean field theory"

Links: [{"title":"Mean-field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical mean-field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_mean-field_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Polymer field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polymer_field_theory"},{"title":"Field (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_(physics)"},{"title":"Field-theoretic simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-theoretic_simulation"},{"title":"Ring (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Identity type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_type"},{"title":"Algebraic quantum field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_quantum_field_theory"},{"title":"Effective theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of mean field theory:

## Definition and Core Concept

Mean-field theory (MFT) or Self-consistent field theory studies the behavior of high-dimensional random (stochastic) models by studying a simpler model that approximates the original by averaging over degrees of freedom (the number of values in the final calculation of a statistic that are free to vary).(no content)The main idea of MFT is to replace all interactions to any one body with an average or effective interaction, sometimes called a molecular field. This reduces any many-body problem into an effective one-body problem.

## Key Advantages

The ease of solving MFT problems means that some insight into the behavior of the system can be obtained at a lower computational cost.

## Theoretical Foundation

The formal basis for mean-field theory is the Bogoliubov inequality. The minimising reference system is then the "best" approximation to the true system using non-correlated degrees of freedom and is known as the mean field approximation.

## Applications and Extensions

MFT has been applied to a wide range of fields outside of physics, including statistical inference, graphical models, neuroscience, artificial intelligence, epidemic models, queueing theory, computer-network performance and more. Additionally, in a variant of mean field theory called dynamical mean field theory (DMFT), the mean field becomes a time-dependent quantity.

## Limitations

Dimensionality plays an active role in determining whether a mean-field approach will work for any particular problem. There is sometimes a critical dimension above which MFT is valid and below which it is not.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Phase transition physics"

Links: [{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Evolution of a random network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_a_random_network"},{"title":"Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_Transitions_and_Critical_Phenomena"},{"title":"Deposition (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deposition_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Phase change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_change"},{"title":"Critical phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_phenomena"},{"title":"Condensed matter physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condensed_phase"},{"title":"Scale invariance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_invariance"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of phase transition physics based on the search results:

## Definition and Basic Concepts

In physics, chemistry and biology, a phase transition is the physical process of transition between one state of a medium and another, commonly referring to changes among the basic states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas, and in rare cases, plasma.

## Types of Phase Transitions

A phase transition usually occurs when the pressure or temperature changes and the system crosses from one region to another, like water turning from liquid to solid as soon as the temperature drops below the freezing point.

Beyond basic matter state changes, phase transitions include several other phenomena:
- The emergence of superconductivity in certain metals and ceramics when cooled below a critical temperature
- Quantum condensation of bosonic fluids (Bose–Einstein condensation)
- Phase transitions can also occur when a solid changes to a different structure without changing its chemical makeup, known as allotropy in elements and polymorphism in compounds

## Classical vs. Quantum Phase Transitions

Classical phase transitions are driven by a competition between the energy of a system and the entropy of its thermal fluctuations, and a classical system does not have entropy at zero temperature and therefore no phase transition can occur.

In contrast, a quantum phase transition is a phase transition between different quantum phases (phases of matter at zero temperature), and quantum phase transitions can only be accessed by varying a physical parameter—such as magnetic field or pressure—at absolute zero temperature.

## Critical Phenomena

Near the critical point, systems undergo critical behavior, wherein several of their properties such as correlation length, specific heat, and magnetic susceptibility diverge exponentially.(no content)It is a remarkable fact that phase transitions arising in different systems often possess the same set of critical exponents, a phenomenon known as universality.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Evolution of a random network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_a_random_network"},{"title":"Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_Transitions_and_Critical_Phenomena"},{"title":"Deposition (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deposition_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Phase change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_change"},{"title":"Critical phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_phenomena"},{"title":"Condensed matter physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condensed_phase"},{"title":"Scale invariance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_invariance"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of phase transition physics based on the search results:

## Definition and Basic Concepts

In physics, chemistry and biology, a phase transition is the physical process of transition between one state of a medium and another, commonly referring to changes among the basic states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas, and in rare cases, plasma.

## Types of Phase Transitions

A phase transition usually occurs when the pressure or temperature changes and the system crosses from one region to another, like water turning from liquid to solid as soon as the temperature drops below the freezing point.

Beyond basic matter state changes, phase transitions include several other phenomena:
- The emergence of superconductivity in certain metals and ceramics when cooled below a critical temperature
- Quantum condensation of bosonic fluids (Bose–Einstein condensation)
- Phase transitions can also occur when a solid changes to a different structure without changing its chemical makeup, known as allotropy in elements and polymorphism in compounds

## Classical vs. Quantum Phase Transitions

Classical phase transitions are driven by a competition between the energy of a system and the entropy of its thermal fluctuations, and a classical system does not have entropy at zero temperature and therefore no phase transition can occur.

In contrast, a quantum phase transition is a phase transition between different quantum phases (phases of matter at zero temperature), and quantum phase transitions can only be accessed by varying a physical parameter—such as magnetic field or pressure—at absolute zero temperature.

## Critical Phenomena

Near the critical point, systems undergo critical behavior, wherein several of their properties such as correlation length, specific heat, and magnetic susceptibility diverge exponentially.(no content)It is a remarkable fact that phase transitions arising in different systems often possess the same set of critical exponents, a phenomenon known as universality.

Based on the search results, here are the main meanings of "nonreciprocal interaction":

## In Biology and Genetics

Nonreciprocal translocation is a chromosomal abnormality that involves the one-way transfer of genes from one chromosome to another non-homologous chromosome.(no content)This transfer will always be unbalanced resulting in genetic imbalance.(no content)In the case of nonreciprocal translocations, the acceptor chromosome gains material but the donor chromosome does not accept material in exchange, and this unequal transfer causes loss of genetic material which may have varying degrees of impact.

## In Physics and Optics

Faraday rotation is an example of non-reciprocal optical propagation.(no content)Unlike what happens in an optically active medium such as a sugar solution, reflecting a polarized beam back through the same Faraday medium does not undo the polarization change the beam underwent in its forward pass through the medium.

In microwave engineering, nonreciprocal gyromagnetic devices such as resonant isolators and differential phase shifters depend on a microwave signal presenting a rotating (circularly polarized) magnetic field to a statically magnetized ferrite body.

In general, nonreciprocal interactions refer to situations where an effect or exchange occurs in one direction without a corresponding or equal effect in the reverse direction.

Links: [{"title":"Vortex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vortex"},{"title":"Quantum vortex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_vortex"},{"title":"Optical vortex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_vortex"},{"title":"Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_defect"},{"title":"Abrikosov vortex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abrikosov_vortex"},{"title":"Type-II superconductor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-II_superconductor"},{"title":"Order operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_operator"},{"title":"Gross–Pitaevskii equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross%E2%80%93Pitaevskii_equation"},{"title":"Vortex shedding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vortex_shedding"},{"title":"Vortex theory of the atom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vortex_theory_of_the_atom"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about vortex defect physics:

## Overview

Quantum vortices are a type of topological defect exhibited in superfluids and superconductors.(no content)Topological defects occur in partial differential equations and are believed to drive phase transitions in condensed matter physics.

## Key Types

### Quantum Vortices
In physics, a quantum vortex represents a quantized flux circulation of some physical quantity.(no content)The existence of quantum vortices was first predicted by Lars Onsager in 1949 in connection with superfluid helium.

### Abrikosov Vortices (in Superconductors)
In superconductivity, a fluxon (also called an Abrikosov vortex or quantum vortex) is a vortex of supercurrent in a type-II superconductor, used by Soviet physicist Alexei Abrikosov to explain magnetic behavior of type-II superconductors.(no content)Abrikosov vortices form a lattice, usually triangular, with the average vortex density (flux density) approximately equal to the externally applied magnetic field.

### In Superfluids
In a superfluid, a quantum vortex "carries" quantized orbital angular momentum, thus allowing the superfluid to rotate; in a superconductor, the vortex carries quantized magnetic flux.

## Physical Characteristics
In mathematics and physics, topological defects are structures in a physical system that are stable against perturbations. Solitons do not decay, dissipate, disperse or evaporate in the way that ordinary waves might. The stability arises from an obstruction to the decay, which is explained by having the soliton belong to a different topological homotopy class or cohomology class than the base physical system. It is not possible to continuously transform the system with a soliton in it, to one without it.

Web search results for query: "Ferromagnetism magnetic ordering"

Links: [{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetic structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_structure"},{"title":"Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetism"},{"title":"Curie temperature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curie_temperature"},{"title":"Paramagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetic domain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weiss_theory_of_ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Multiferroics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiferroic"},{"title":"Magnetic hysteresis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_hysteresis"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ferromagnetism and magnetic ordering:

## Ferromagnetism

Ferromagnetism is a property of certain materials (such as iron) that results in a significant, observable magnetic permeability, and in many cases, a significant magnetic coercivity, allowing the material to form a permanent magnet.(no content)Ferromagnetism (along with the similar effect ferrimagnetism) is the strongest type and is responsible for the common phenomenon of everyday magnetism.

## Magnetic Ordering

The term magnetic structure of a material pertains to the ordered arrangement of magnetic spins, typically within an ordered crystallographic lattice.(no content)Magnetic domains form in materials which have magnetic ordering; that is, their dipoles spontaneously align due to the exchange interaction. These are the ferromagnetic, ferrimagnetic and antiferromagnetic materials.

## How Ferromagnetism Works

In addition to the electrons' intrinsic magnetic moment's tendency to be parallel to an applied field, there is also in these materials a tendency for these magnetic moments to orient parallel to each other to maintain a lowered-energy state.(no content)Below the Curie temperature, virtually all of the dipoles in a ferromagnetic material will be aligned.

## Temperature Effects

Every ferromagnetic substance has its own individual temperature, called the Curie temperature, or Curie point, above which it loses its ferromagnetic properties. This is because the thermal tendency to disorder overwhelms the energy-lowering due to ferromagnetic order.

## Common Ferromagnetic Materials

Relatively few materials are ferromagnetic; the common ones are the metals iron, cobalt, nickel and most of their alloys, and certain rare-earth metals.

Ferromagnetism is a property of certain materials (such as iron) that results in a significant, observable magnetic permeability, and in many cases, a significant magnetic coercivity, allowing the material to form a permanent magnet.(no content)Ferromagnetism (along with the similar effect ferrimagnetism) is the strongest type and is responsible for the common phenomenon of everyday magnetism.

## Magnetic Ordering

The term magnetic structure of a material pertains to the ordered arrangement of magnetic spins, typically within an ordered crystallographic lattice.(no content)Magnetic domains form in materials which have magnetic ordering; that is, their dipoles spontaneously align due to the exchange interaction. These are the ferromagnetic, ferrimagnetic and antiferromagnetic materials.

## How Ferromagnetism Works

In addition to the electrons' intrinsic magnetic moment's tendency to be parallel to an applied field, there is also in these materials a tendency for these magnetic moments to orient parallel to each other to maintain a lowered-energy state.(no content)Below the Curie temperature, virtually all of the dipoles in a ferromagnetic material will be aligned.

## Temperature Effects

Every ferromagnetic substance has its own individual temperature, called the Curie temperature, or Curie point, above which it loses its ferromagnetic properties. This is because the thermal tendency to disorder overwhelms the energy-lowering due to ferromagnetic order.

## Common Ferromagnetic Materials

Relatively few materials are ferromagnetic; the common ones are the metals iron, cobalt, nickel and most of their alloys, and certain rare-earth metals.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Nonreciprocal Ising Model" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes novel methodology)

**Key Findings:**

I extracted **10 triples** representing the key technologies and methodologies in the paper:

**Uses (7 triples):**
- Ising model - foundational statistical mechanics model
- Phase transition - core theoretical framework
- Mean-field theory - analytical approach
- Critical exponent - characterizes phase transitions
- Active matter - application domain with nonreciprocal interactions
- Topological defect - framework for understanding defects
- Ferromagnetism - underlying physical phenomenon

**Proposes (3 triples):**
- Nonreciprocal Ising model - novel generalization with nonreciprocal interactions
- Droplet-capture mechanism - new stabilizing mechanism discovered
- Spiral defect - new defect type emerging in 2D nonreciprocal systems

All triples have been validated and include:
- Proper entity types (8 concepts, 2 methods)
- Wikipedia URLs for reference
- Clear relevance statements explaining their importance to the research

The output file is ready at: `/home/adrian/projects/ai-inventor/aii_pipeline/src/aii_pipeline/steps/_prep_context/invention_kg/data/_4_triples/144_20251218_011448/paper_00119/agent_cwd/triples_output.json`
